method: Heat half the oil in a large heavy-based pan. Add the onion and cook until softened. Tip it onto a plate.
Return the pan to the heat and add the remaining oil. When hot, fry the mince in batches for 4–5 minutes until browned all over.
Stir in the cooked onion and tomato purée and cook for 1 minute. Stir in the flour and cook for another minute. Pour in the red wine, scraping up caramelised bits, then add the thyme.
Add the stock and simmer for 45 minutes until the mince is tender and the mixture has thickened. Season to taste and add Worcestershire sauce. Keep warm over very low heat.
For the mash, boil the potatoes in salted water for 12–15 minutes until tender.
Drain and return potatoes to the pan. Heat for 1 minute to remove moisture. Mash well, then add butter and milk, beating to form a smooth mash. Season to taste.
Preheat grill to high. Spoon the filling into a baking dish and spread mash over the top. Grill for 8–10 minutes until golden-brown.
Boil peas in boiling water for 3–4 minutes, drain, and add butter. Serve the cottage pie with the peas.

ingredients.ingredient: Chicken Thighs Bone In Skin Removed

method: Pour or scrape out the yoghurt into a dish large enough for the chicken pieces in a single layer. Add sambal oelek, kecap manis, tamarind paste, grated ginger, garlic, cinnamon, cardamom, ground turmeric, salt, and vegetable oil and stir to combine.
Add the skinless bone-in chicken thighs to the marinade, coating them well. Leave to marinate while preparing the onions.
Heat oil in a large wide non-stick pan or casserole with a lid. Cook onions on high for 5 minutes, then cook stirring frequently for 20 to 30 minutes until soft and pale.

Remove chicken from marinade with tongs and arrange bone-side down in pan, pushing onions over them. Pour remaining marinade over chicken, turn heat to high, cover with lid and cook for 15 minutes at a fast simmer.
Remove lid, turn chicken pieces over, mix in sauce and simmer uncovered for 30 minutes until chicken is cooked and sauce thickened. Remove chicken if sauce is still runny and reduce sauce on its own.
Return chicken and sauce to the dish it marinated in and cool. Cover and refrigerate overnight or up to two days. Debone and tear chicken into chunks before reheating.

For the rice, put cardamom pods, cinnamon stick, cloves, star anise, desiccated coconut and pink peppercorns in a large pan. Add 2 liters water, sea salt, lime juice and sesame oil. Bring to boil, then turn off heat and keep covered on warm hob.
Rinse rice and soak in cold water for 30 minutes. Near end of soaking, reheat chicken gently and bring scented water to boil.
Drain rice well and add gradually to boiling water. Cover and return to boil, then boil for 2 minutes. Test rice by rubbing a grain between fingers to check if it breaks into 2 or 3 bits. Drain well.

Wipe pan and brush bottom with sesame oil. Add half the rice, sprinkle half the toasted cumin seeds, desiccated coconut and cranberries. Arrange reheated chicken evenly on rice, spooning over any sauce. Cover with remaining rice and sprinkle remaining cumin, coconut and cranberries.
Seal pot top with foil and lid. Place on medium heat for 4 to 5 minutes until steam starts, then reduce heat and cook for 15 to 16 minutes more.
Turn off heat, remove foil carefully to release steam, replace foil with clean tea towel and clamp lid. Leave off heat for 20 minutes or longer.
Cook reserved chicken skin in air fryer at maximum temperature for 12 to 18 minutes until crisp. Keep chicken fat rendered from skins for later use.
Spoon biryani onto platter, arrange chicken and meat attractively. Scrape bottom of pot for crispy bits and crumble chicken crackling over top. Scatter with freshly chopped coriander.
Put the onion and celery into a food processor and blitz to a mush or chop very finely by hand. Reserve 2 tablespoons of the mixture for the meatballs.
Warm garlic oil in a large saucepan over moderate-low heat. Add the onion and celery mixture and dried thyme. Cook, stirring occasionally, for 10 minutes.

Add chopped tomatoes and fill empty cans with water to add to the pan. Add sugar, sea salt, and pepper to taste. Stir well and bring to a bubble. Reduce heat and simmer gently while preparing meatballs.
In a large bowl, mix turkey mince, free range egg, breadcrumbs, parmesan, Worcestershire sauce, dried thyme, reserved onion and celery mixture. Mix gently by hand without overmixing.
Roll mixture into meatballs about the size of a heaped teaspoon. Place on baking tray lined with parchment paper. You should get about 50 meatballs.
Drop meatballs gently into simmering sauce in concentric circles around the pan.
Simmer meatballs in sauce for 30 minutes or until cooked through.
Serve with rice, pasta, couscous, or preferred accompaniment.

Put the chicken thigh fillets into a mixing bowl and add the olive oil, Cajun seasoning, garlic powder, oregano, juice of half a lemon, and a pinch of salt. Mix well and marinate for up to 30 minutes in the fridge.

To make the hummus, drain the cannellini beans, reserving 100ml of the bean water. Add the beans, reserved water, juice of half a lemon, garlic cloves, tahini, and a pinch of salt to a blender. Blend until smooth.
Preheat the grill to high. Arrange the chicken on a grill rack and grill for 4–5 minutes on each side until cooked through. Slice the chicken and season with a little salt.
Alternatively, air fry the chicken in batches at 220°C for 10–12 minutes, turning halfway, until cooked through and crispy.
For the salad, put the red onion into a bowl with juice of half a lemon and a pinch of salt. Mix well and leave to mellow. Just before serving, add the shredded lettuce and toss together.
To serve, spread the hummus onto the flatbreads, top with the sliced chicken and salad. Serve with chilli sauce if desired.
Put the onion and celery into a food processor and blitz to a mush. Reserve 2 tablespoons of the mixture for the meatballs.

Warm the garlic oil in a large, heavy-based saucepan or casserole, add the onion and celery mixture, along with the thyme, and cook at a moderate to low heat, stirring every now and again, for about 10 minutes.

Add the chopped tomatoes, filling up each empty can with water to add to the pan. Season with the sugar, stir well and let the mixture come to a bubble, then turn the heat down and simmer the sauce gently while you get on with the meatballs.

For the meatballs, put the turkey mince, egg, breadcrumbs, parmesan, Worcestershire sauce, dried thyme, and the reserved chopped onion and celery into a large bowl and gently mix together with your hands. Don’t overmix, as that will make the meatballs dense-textured and heavy.

When all the meatball ingredients are combined, start rolling them into balls. Pinch out an amount about the size of a generously heaped teaspoon and roll it into a ball between the palms of your hands. Put each meatball onto a baking tray lined with baking parchment or greaseproof paper. You should get about 50 little meatballs.
Drop the meatballs gently into the simmering sauce, letting them fall in concentric circles working round the pan from the outside edge inwards.
Let the meatballs simmer in the sauce for 30 minutes, or until cooked through. Serve with rice, pasta, couscous or as desired.
Remove seeds from the cardamom pods and grind them with the coriander seeds to a fine powder. Chop the garlic to form a paste.
In a bowl, mix the beef and pork mince together vigorously to soften the texture.
Add the ground spices, turmeric, garlic paste, and beaten egg to the meat mixture. Mix thoroughly.
With wet hands, form the mixture into approximately 12 ping-pong-sized balls.
Lightly oil a clean surface and flatten each meatball into a circle.
Place a teaspoon of cream cheese in the center of each circle and fold the meat around it to enclose the cheese completely, ensuring there are no holes.
Heat a frying pan over medium-high heat, add the remaining oil, and fry the meatballs for about 10 minutes, turning regularly until cooked through. Transfer to a serving dish and keep warm.
Increase the heat, add the halved tomatoes to the pan, and flash-fry them quickly. Remove from heat and stir in the yoghurt.
For the salad, toss together the salad leaves, mint, chives, parsley, and oregano in a large bowl. Whisk the vinegar, mustard, and olive oil together, then toss with the salad leaves.
To serve, arrange the salad around the edge of a platter, place the meatballs in the center, pour the tomato and yoghurt mixture over the meatballs, and garnish with almonds and fried shallots.

recipeName: Pan-fried Gnocchi, Crispy Sausage and Broccoli
method: Drizzle 2 tablespoons of olive oil into a large, lidded, flameproof frying pan and place on a high heat. Add the gnocchi to the pan and fry for around 2 minutes, tossing occasionally, until it becomes a little charred all over. Transfer to a plate and set aside.

Keep the pan off the heat and squeeze the sausage meat out of the sausage skins into the pan, roughly breaking it up as you go. Place the pan on a medium-high heat, add another tablespoon of olive oil and fry the sausage meat for around 5–8 minutes, until coloured and cooked through.

Add the garlic and fennel seeds to the pan, then after a minute add all of the broccoli. Fry for a further minute, then pour in the wine. Bring it to the boil, allow to boil for a minute, then cover with a lid and reduce the heat a little. Cook for around 3 minutes, or until the broccoli is just cooked. At this point preheat the grill to high.

When the broccoli is ready, drizzle with the honey. Stir in the fried gnocchi and dot over the taleggio. Pop the pan under the grill and grill for 3–5 minutes, until the cheese is oozy and everything is slightly blistered. Serve with a rocket salad on the side.
Put the chicken thighs in a bowl with the ground turmeric, lime juice, and sunflower oil. Toss together well and set aside for 10 minutes.

To make the sauce, heat the sunflower oil in a saucepan and add the cumin seeds. Once they start to sizzle, add the chopped onion, garlic, and ginger and cook gently for 5–6 minutes over a low heat, or until well softened, stirring regularly.

Tip the chopped tomatoes and tomato purée into the pan and cook for another 2 minutes, stirring. Next, stir in the ground turmeric, garam masala, and chilli powder. Add the ground almonds and full-fat milk and cook on a low heat for 10 minutes, or until thickened, stirring regularly.
While the sauce is cooking, heat a griddle pan or heavy-based frying pan. Cook the chicken pieces for 8–10 minutes, or until lightly browned and cooked through, turning occasionally.

Add the chicken to the sauce, cover loosely, and simmer gently together for 5–6 minutes, stirring regularly. If it becomes too thick, add a splash of water. If you have time, leave the curry to stand for 30 minutes before serving, then reheat gently. Serve with cooked rice on the side and fresh coriander scattered over.
Mix the pork mince, onion, garlic, and dried herbs in a large bowl until thoroughly combined. Divide into 20 even portions and roll into small balls.

Pour the oil into a medium lidded frying pan or sauté pan and place over a medium heat. Fry the meatballs for 10 minutes, turning regularly until well browned on all sides. Transfer to a plate and return the pan to the heat without wiping or washing.

For the gravy, melt the butter with the oil over a low heat in the same frying pan. Fry the sliced onion for about 5 minutes, or until softened and lightly browned, stirring regularly. Stir in the tomato purée and herbs and cook for 30 seconds, stirring constantly.

Sprinkle the flour into the pan, stir well and cook for a few seconds, then gradually add 300ml of cold water, stirring well after each addition. Increase the heat and bring the gravy to a simmer. Cook for 2–3 minutes, stirring constantly.

Carefully strain the gravy through a sieve into a large bowl, pressing the onions with the back of a spoon to release as much flavour as possible. Pour the liquid back into the pan and stir in 400ml of cold water, then add the meatballs and any resting juices.
Cover loosely with a lid and simmer gently for 25–30 minutes, stirring occasionally until the meatballs are tender and the gravy is thick enough to lightly coat them.
Heat the olive oil in a large pan with a lid over medium heat. Roll the sausage meat into small, equally-sized meatballs and add them to the pan.
Fry for 5–6 minutes, stirring occasionally, until browned on all sides. Remove the meatballs with a slotted spoon and set aside.
Add the onion and fennel to the pan. Cook, stirring occasionally, for 5–6 minutes or until slightly softened.
Add the garlic, tomato purée, and oregano. Cook until fragrant. Pour in the white wine to deglaze the pan, stirring well, and cook for 2–3 minutes more.
Add the chopped tomatoes, chicken stock, and cooked meatballs. Stir together and bring to the boil. Cover with a lid, reduce the heat to low, and simmer for 30 minutes.
Increase the heat and bring the soup to a gentle boil. Add the tortellini, spinach, and double cream. Stir well and cook for 1–2 minutes or until the tortellini is just cooked.
Serve immediately into bowls with a sprinkle of grated Parmesan.
